tagDescription: to McDonald. Remarks on his health and the (Vist) NorthWest people.
to Charles McLean. Instructions regarding Hudson's Bay settlers.
to McDonald. Selection of officers for Hudson's Bay Military establishment.
to McDonald. Suggesting another point for his enquiries at Fort William.
to McDonald. Regarding publications Scottish newspapers for and against emigration to the Hudson's Bay Company.
to McDonald. Referring to men required by Hudson's Bay Co.
to McDonald. Memo.on journey from York Fort to Port Nelson to the outlet of Lake Winnipeg.
Alex McDonald's memo. of Lord Seaforth's lands.
to McDonald. Referring to letters written.
to McDonald. Regarding their meeting at Stirling.
to Selkirk. Departure of young McDonald.Funds forwarded for Mason.
to McDonald. Enclosing letter from Archibald McDonald regarding preparations prior to the sailing of ships conveying settlers to Red River.
to McDonald. Leaves for Edinburgh. 1300 men,women and children wish to go to Canada.
to McDonald. Difficulty in finding a suitable person for object named in letter from Fort William.
to Selkirk. Requests information on progress at Red River. Highland proprietors anxious to get rid of their people.Is sending a few settlers to tract reserved for himself which he has named Dalilia.
to McDonald. Is on the way home and will meet at Callender.
to Selkirk. Remarks on military plan proposed officers.
to Selkirk. Enclosing letter from Hugh Leslie regarding consideration for Hudson's Bay Company servants.
to McDonald. Commission in Kirkcudbright militia available for his brother.
to McDonald. Relative to observations on proposed Hudson's Bay Military establishment.
to McDonald. Approves of Keanloch being in charge of North Vist people.
to McDonald. Will meet in Edinburgh 16 November.Vacancy in Galloway Militia for his relative.

to McDonald. Is sailing for Red River on board the Pacific via New York and Montreal. Lady Selkirk and the childred accompany him to Montreal.Mr.Colvile to he notified if clerks apply for Hudson's Bay service.
to McDonald. Referring to the appointment of ---McDonald to Hudson's Bay Co. Terms offered to men. Questions amount of bounty.
to McDonald. Engagement of new settlers.Letters received from Red River reporting affairs and conditions.
to McDonald. Requests information regarding father of Archibald McDonald.
to McDonald. Emigration plan.Inducements to young men.
to McDonald. Referring to draft to Mr.Roberts.
to Alex.McDonald. Regarding settlers for Red River. His own success and the responsibility placed upon him by Selkirk.
to McDonald. Requests information regarding the value of Lord Seaforth's estates.(Reply in margin giving values.)
to McDonald. Expressing sympathy.Refers to education of Archibald McDonald.
to Alex. McDonald. Expresses wish to meet him in Edinburgh.
to McDonald. Will be at Stirling on 25th inst.
to McDonald, Changing place of meeting to Edinburgh.
to McDonald. Reports from Red River.
to McDonald. Progress of Assiboia plan and observations on Red River by Archibald Mason. Information relative to Mason himself.
to McDonald. Report regarding Mason's conduct. Instructions relative to sailing.
to McDonald. Purchase of Lord Seaforth's lands. Archibald McDonald and the men engaged with him.
to McDonald. Notifying him of arrival.
to McDonald. Referring to drafts of Charles McLean and Archibald McDonald on his account.
to McDonald. Relative to Hudson's Bay affairs in the Assiniboine district. Families as desirable settlers.
to McDonald. Relative to military establishment for Hudson's Bay.Proposal to be made to government regarding same.
to Selkirk. Regarding emigrants wishing to accompany Archibald McDonald to Canada. Duncan McDonald goes as clerk to the Hudson's Bay CO.
to McDonald. Enclosing letter for Mr.Borsdale,Fort William.Distribution of land. Allowance for shepherd.
to McDonald. Will meet him at Falkirk.
to McDonald. Remarks on Seaforth estates. Peerage election.
to Charles McLean. Regarding the settlers for Red River.
to McDonald. Method for securing men for the Hudson's Bay service.Appointment of schoolmaster for Red River.
to McDonald. Regarding Archibald McDonald's distressing account of the voyage to Churchill Fort.
to McDonald. Further remarks relative to Hudson's Bay Military establishment
